stream_context.summary: Kaze tests a new Sauraen-built trace/profiler to understand RTYI’s frame-time breakdown (revealing heavy idle/memory wait time), then switches to hands-on integration of Biobak’s updated “Oily Boily Bay” enemy/NPC assets to improve visuals and performance. He also reviews and iterates on Course 13’s snowman cave/slide difficulty, explains a prior crash caused by collision memory limits, discusses increased control-angle precision vs vanilla SM64, and fixes a buggy Wiggler path/animation setup.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a powerful new profiling tool (Sauraen) with concrete performance revelations; contains a clear technical explanation of a real crash (collision surface-node allocation) and a key systemic change (much higher angle precision). Also shows the team’s performance-driven art iteration with Biobak’s asset revisions targeting 30 FPS in Oily Boily Bay and includes a full debugging arc for Wiggler pathing.

findings.summary: Kaze demonstrates Sauraen’s new trace+profiler and finds RTYI spends roughly 25ms of a ~33ms frame in idle (a while(1) loop), i.e., ~76% of the frame is effectively the game waiting/doing nothing, suggesting a major wait/bottleneck component rather than pure CPU work.
findings.quote: Funny thing about RTYI: 25 out of 33 milliseconds are spent on a while(1) loop. It’s all idle. It’s around 76% of the entire game.

findings.summary: Profiler inspection suggests scheduling/synchronization issues: Kaze notes unexpectedly long scheduler/VI manager time and hypothesizes the game loop may be blocked by a missing RSP-done signal, based on gaps where nothing obvious should block execution.

Kaze notes the RDP appears to run slightly longer than the GFX task, which he reads as a bad sign (RSP bottlenecking) and uses FPS limiting/unlimiting to illustrate how thread activity changes under different pacing.

In Course 13’s snowman cave/slide section (inspired by the Jolly Roger Bay ship-climb tension), Kaze flags difficulty/readability problems (spiky slide geometry and poor visibility of incoming hazards). He considers scaling the slide down to raise camera horizon rather than forcing camera tilt changes.

Kaze explains a prior Course 13 slide crash: large collision triangles crossing multiple spatial cells require extra ‘surface node’ allocations; because the slide was huge, the game ran out of memory and crashed. This incident pushed him to redo memory allocation work, which also improved performance by about 400 microseconds.
findings.quote: Every time you have a collision triangle that crosses into multiple cells… you have to allocate two surface nodes. And because the slide was so big I had to allocate so many surface nodes that the whole thing just crashed.

findings.summary: RTYI’s movement/control math differs from vanilla SM64: Kaze states SM64 uses 4096 angles, while RTYI uses 65336, making control direction ~8x more precise. This means identical setups for precise-angle speedrun tricks (e.g., carpetless variants) may not behave the same because the game tracks closer to true stick direction.
findings.quote: In Mario 64 you have 4096 angles. In this game you have 65336 angles… the controls are about 8 times more precise.

findings.summary: Kaze attributes improved angle precision partly to performance-driven math changes: he replaced trig/atan lookups with a polynomial for speed, which ended up more accurate than SM64’s lookup table.

Biobak delivers a large batch of updated Oily Boily Bay assets with explicit performance goals (fewer materials, fewer bones, updated textures/geo/collision). Kaze repeatedly confirms the new versions look better with fog and should allow Oily Boily Bay to hit 30 FPS.
findings.quote: Dang, I think we can get Oily Boily Bay at 30 FPS now.

findings.summary: Kaze actively optimizes art import settings: he switches assets away from CI when there are too many unique colors, prefers RGBA16 in that scenario, and highlights exporter/tooling pitfalls (Fast64 picking the wrong texture/detector types; fog preview inconsistencies).

Kaze identifies gameplay-side side effects of engine/collision tweaks: updated ‘step function’/collision behavior makes it easier to clip through certain hazards (tox boxes), and he investigates/fixes a ‘jump’ at the end of a rolling motion.

Wiggler behavior debugging: Kaze discovers erratic turning was caused by his own waypoint/path logic (treating waypoints like jumps and skipping points based on distance/velocity checks). He removes the unnecessary logic, restores proper ‘trajectory end’ handling, and confirms Wiggler pathing and facial animations now behave correctly.
Kaze briefly notes Zeina is producing 3D models for a new overworld entrance area while he tries building the new overworld himself, implying parallel workstreams (world art vs implementation).
Kaze mentions he is on paternity leave and continues development/optimization during that time; he shares the baby’s planned name (Raina) and that the due date has passed by a couple days.
findings.quote: I’m still on two months of paternity leave. I’m gonna spend that time trying to optimize the operating system on my N64.

biobak.summary: Biobak provides multiple updated enemy/NPC models for Oily Boily Bay with performance notes: shared bones (both legs use the same bone), baked details into textures (helmet strap) to save materials, updated geo and collision to match the new look, and overall reductions in bones/material count.

Biobak’s updates aim to better match the area’s modernized ‘construction/junkyard’ aesthetic (e.g., tox boxes and worker characters fitting the world more convincingly once fog and textures are applied).

zeina.summary: Zeina is referenced as creating 3D models/assets for the new overworld entrance while Kaze experiments with building the overworld layout/implementation.

findings.summary: Sauraen created the new trace+profiler tool Kaze is using to measure thread/task timelines (idle thread, game loop, VI manager, audio/RSP/RDP activity), enabling Kaze to spot blocking/synchronization anomalies.
Sauraen previously advised that certain shading/normal tricks may not work under F3DEX3 because it auto-normalizes normals, affecting how Kaze can implement sharp edges/normal hacks.
Lilaa participates in troubleshooting Blender/Fast64 export issues around normals (Kaze attempting scripts and split normals) though no definitive solution is reached in this stream.

key_stories.title: Adopting Sauraen’s profiler and discovering ‘idle time’ dominance
key_stories.summary: Kaze showcases a new trace/profiler (built by Sauraen and integrated by Kaze) and immediately finds that most frame time is spent in an idle loop rather than executing game logic. The trace also reveals unusually long scheduler/VI manager activity and suspicious gaps that suggest synchronization problems.
key_stories.challenge: Optimization was previously harder to target without a clear timeline view of threads/tasks, and frame pacing issues weren’t attributable to a single obvious function.
key_stories.process: Kaze uses FPS limiting to stabilize readings, compares task durations (RSP/RDP/GFX/audio), and reasons about priority/blocking based on trace gaps.
key_stories.outcome: He identifies the dominant ‘waiting/idle’ share of the frame and forms a concrete hypothesis: a missing RSP-done signal could be blocking the game loop unexpectedly.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s around 76% of the entire game, it’s just the game doing nothing at all.

key_stories.title: Course 13 slide: difficulty tuning forced by collision memory limits
key_stories.summary: While iterating on Course 13’s snowman cave/slide sequence, Kaze explains that the original slide build caused a crash due to collision surface-node allocation limits. That incident led him to rework memory allocation and incidentally gain measurable performance headroom.
key_stories.challenge: A large, spiky slide both played poorly (hard to slide forward, visibility issues) and exceeded collision memory constraints due to how SM64 partitions collision into cells.
key_stories.process: Kaze considers design-side fixes (scaling slide to improve camera horizon vs forced camera tilt), and recalls implementing allocator changes after the crash.
key_stories.outcome: The section is made easier/readable, and the project benefits from allocator improvements (reported ~400 microseconds saved). The design remains open to further tuning.
key_stories.key_quote: Because of that I did the whole memory allocation thing… and because of that we gained 400 microseconds of computing time.

key_stories.title: Biobak’s asset revisions push Oily Boily Bay toward 30 FPS
key_stories.summary: Kaze imports a large set of Biobak’s updated Oily Boily Bay assets and applies fog/format changes to improve both look and performance. The updates include fewer bones, fewer materials, and baked texture details, aligning visuals with the area’s industrial construction vibe.
key_stories.challenge: Oily Boily Bay needed better performance and cohesion; too many materials/colors and heavy rigs can be costly on N64-era rendering constraints.
key_stories.process: Kaze audits materials/combiner settings, switches texture formats (CI vs RGBA16) based on unique colors, and validates animations/collision while noting tool/export quirks (Fast64 choices).
key_stories.outcome: Kaze believes the level can now hit 30 FPS ‘pretty easily’ with these changes, though he flags some collision/clipping and minor visual issues to resolve.
key_stories.key_quote: Dang, I think we can get Oily Boily Bay at 30 FPS now.

key_stories.title: Wiggler pathing bug traced to waypoint skipping logic
key_stories.summary: Kaze notices Wiggler turning early and wandering unpredictably despite seemingly correct waypoints. After instrumenting values and reasoning through ‘trajectory end’ behavior, he realizes he previously implemented waypoints as ‘jumps’ and was skipping nodes under certain distance/velocity conditions.
key_stories.challenge: Actor path logic produced confusing, inconsistent movement, undermining a key setpiece and making animations/faces hard to validate.
key_stories.process: Kaze prints waypoint values during runtime, inspects the conditions that advance the waypoint index, and removes the unnecessary skipping behavior.
key_stories.outcome: Wiggler follows the intended path again and facial animations work properly when Wiggler becomes upset.
